After many attempts to arrange a safe and healthy way to have the Valley Prom for 2020, we have been unable to find a suitable and safe scenario.
We understand that the time since March 13, 2020 has been crazy and unfortunate for the class of 2020, the circumstances are out of our hands.

Thank you and Stay Healthy,

Scott Rolfe
Jane Thayer

Headbands for Hospitals to Battle Covid-19

The Engineering Program at Scioto County CTC and Valley High School are making Headbands that will be used for Face Shields at Local hospitals and Health Care Facilities. Craig Tackett (The Engineering Instructor of these Programs) says that they hope to make around 60 headbands a week during this time. Mr. Tackett says that Jared Gahm (Valley Junior and a student of the CTC Engineering Program) is volunteering by using his home 3D printer to help make these. “Jared is helping a lot with this project, and is making lots of headbands”, said Mr. Tackett. “It’s such a great thing to see students like Jared so eager to help make a difference.” Mr. Tackett would also like to thank the administration at both schools for allowing use of the lab equipment to help with such a great cause. Also, Mr. Tackett would also like to thank Ryan Hawk (Technology Coordinator) for getting us in touch with the organization distributing these masks.

Students in Mrs. Kelly Montgomery’s advanced art classes at Valley High School are pictured with the banners they created for downtown Portsmouth through an Artist-in-Residency with artist, Klaire Smith, and in a collaboration with the Friends of Portsmouth group. The banners are displayed on Chillicothe Street with each snowflake design being unique to each banner. On Friday, December 13, the students traveled to Portsmouth for a field trip where they visited the Second Presbyterian Church (to learn about the history and architecture of the church), the Human Rights Garden (to learn about another student-driven community art project), and the floodwall murals (to learn about the artistic processes that were used to create the murals). They then went to see their banners on display.
The project was coordinated by Sharee Price of the South Central Ohio Educational Service Center and was sponsored by the Scioto Foundation, Portsmouth Rotary Club, and SOMC.

VHS Cheerleaders Donate to SOMC Compassion Fund & Backpack Community Service
VHS Cheerleaders donated $1,058 raised this fall from the breast cancer t-shirts sold in our local community. The check was presented at SOMC Cancer Center on November 21 to staff for The SOMC Compassion Fund. This fund assists patients undergoing cancer treatment with hygiene products and items. Also, our cheerleaders supported River Days candidate, Maribeth Thompson, and their community by filling backpacks with school supplies for Portsmouth area students back in August. We are appreciative of our cheerleaders and advisor for taking on these initiatives, and giving back to our community in need. Go Indians!
